thread.title: Jake Henry records 3 TDs, one INT in win over Escambia
thread.title_full: Jake Henry records 3 TDs, one INT in win over Escambia

title: Jake Henry records 3 TDs, one INT in win over Escambia
text:
Jake Henry records 3 TDs, one INT in win over Escambia BRIAN ACHATZ, bachatz@pnj.com 10:54 p.m. CDT October 20, 2015 Jake Henry of Tate has been one of the most versatile players in the area this season with 7 receiving TDs and 5 interceptions. (Photo: Ben Twingley/btwingley@pnj.com) 37 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Heading into this prep football season, it was the Tate Aggies who possessed the largest group of seniors returning to the team in the area. 
For that, the Aggies were one of the favorites for top team in the area. 
Tate (6-1, 2-0 in District 2-6A) has lived up to the hype, with the Aggies lone loss coming by three points to state powerhouse Niceville. 
And while Tate’s seniors have been fulfilling their expectations, it has been junior Jake Henry who has also been a star player for Tate ... and is arguably the area’s most versatile talent this season. 
The Aggies knew they could count on Henry to continue what he started last season (2014 PNJ All-Area team) at defensive back. But when Henry was called up to play receiver this season, even he wasn’t exactly sure what to expect. Tate knocks off Escambia, eyes district title game 
“This is my first year playing receiver ... I like it a lot,” said Henry, who has racked up 772 reception yards for 7 TDs on 32 catches this season. “It is something new. I just like being on the field.” 
Last week, as Tate clinched a playoff spot, Henry exploded for for 208 receiving yards and three TDs. Henry also added an interception – his fifth of the year – and a touchdown saving tackle on defense. 
“We are staying hungry, we want to go as far as we can this season,” Henry said. “We want to be the team to beat, and I believe we are doing a good job of that. 
“Offensively, our o-line is doing a great job. Our running backs are picking up yards and getting clutch first downs. Our receivers are getting open and running good routes. Sawyer (Smith) has been making good reads and playing really good this year.” 
Though Henry holds fond memories from last Friday’s win, he and the Aggies anxiously await a shot at Choctaw this Friday. 
“It was definitely one of my better games (against Escambia), no doubt,” Henry said. 
Catholic banged up after final district game 
The Smiley brothers (Abram, 9th grade; Simeon, 12th grade) have a lot in common. 
Both are impact players for Catholic’s varsity football team (Abram Smiley, No. 4 in area 874 rushing yards heading into last week; Simeon Smiley 2015 PNJ Super Senior). Unfortunately, the similarities don’t stop there as the brothers both suffered injuries in last week’s loss and seem doubtful for this Friday vs. Washington 
“Both of them got hurt against Taylor County, and both won’t play this week (against Washington),” Catholic coach Greg Seibert said. “Simeon has got a MCL sprain ... he got rolled up on. Abram hurt his foot. He kind of jumped over a guy and when he planted his foot, I think he hurt one of his bones.” 
Outside of the Smiley brothers, the injury bug continues to bite Catholic. 
“We also won’t have A.J. Yates this week, who suffered a high-ankle sprain against Taylor County,” Seibert said. 
Yates is ranked No. 11 in the area amongst receivers, after hauling in 17 catches for 245 yards and two TDs prior to the Taylor County game. 
Catholic makes mental transition 
It’s amazing the drama that can be created in prep football when it comes to district play – especially in a three-team district. 
The Catholic Crusaders – in District 1-3A with Taylor County and Florida High – have felt both the highs and the lows of that scenario. 
In Week 6, Catholic bested Florida High (4-1 at the time) with a score of 19-13, as Catholic was half way to its goal of being district champion. 
But after last Friday, the Crusaders took a tumble at home with a 35-26 loss to Taylor County. 
Now, Catholic must play the waiting game as Taylor County and Florida High face off on Oct. 30. 
“Unfortunately, we no longer control our destiny,” Catholic coach Greg Seibert said. “We’ve kind of gotta be Florida High fans. If Florida High beats Taylor County, there will be a shootout. If that doesn’t happen, then we’ll get ready to be the district runner up. The bottom line is our playoff life is still there, it’s just a matter of how it is gonna fit into the rest of our season.” 
Reaching crunch time in District 1-5A 
The fact is, both West Florida and Pensacola High are facing elimination this Friday night. 
For PHS, it is simple, the Tigers must beat the Mosley Dolphins this Friday or their playoff hopes are over. 
But a win for PHS over Mosley would make things tricky for the West Florida Jaguars, who face Arnold on Friday. 
For the Jags’ to be eliminated, West Florida would have to lose to Arnold and Mosley would have to defeat Pensacola. 37 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://on.pnj.com/1LJNQ7h TOP VIDEOS
